message: Agree with @mimazim, add "why you chose <your choice> over GoDaddy?" for future feedback would be great
Mainly because I want to go away from GoDaddy
Thanks for all the feedback going to check both name.com and hover.com
I like name.com  moved my domains there a while ago and I'm happy with it.

I've been migrating domains from godaddy to moniker.com over the past year (80 so far). I only chose them because I read some comparative reviews and they seemed to be the choice of no-nonsense domain professionals. I like that you can fill an account with credits and use them as necessary - no need to enter purchasing info every time you reg or renew a domain. And the interface is good (though just about anyone's UI would be an improvement over GoDaddy).
I haven't been on it for very long, but so far, I like hover.com

name.com is where I'm migrating all my domains to, as they come up for expiration.  It's been 2 years in the making, and I think I still have about 15 or so domains on GoDaddy (and a couple on Dotster too), but I'm almost there.

@mirnazim Name.com has a drop-dead simple interface and doesn't try to upsell me on anything (or at least doesn't try noticeably hard).  I originally started using GoDaddy over Dotster when Dotster started charging to host my DNS.  Now Godaddy is charging for 'premium' DNS hosting, Name.com doesn't.  I was moving to Name based on recommendations from HN before GoDaddy started DNS upcharging, but that accelerated it.
I haven't used it, but hover.com will cover the cost of switching with a promo code from http://thisweekin.com/thisweekin-web/
It would be great to know why you chose <your choice> over GoDaddy
I would be mostly sold only on simple interface :P

I moved to hover.com much the same reasons that @bmelton moved to name.com: Good interface, reasonable rates, mild upsell. Hover's excellent "how to migrate your domain" documentation seemed indicative of a customer service oriented company which didn't hurt either.
I use namecheap. Interface is functional, only slightly awkward. No BS.
After the whole elephant fiasco I finally moved all my domains over to NameCheap, no complaints thus far.
For what it's worth, I actively dislike NameCheap's DNS interface.  Anything tricky with DNS just isn't allowed.

+1 for hover.com. Just make sure you turn off the email option (it's $45 by default). I just transferred all my domains there. Transfer fee is $10 and that adds a year to whatever your current expiration is. Lastly, their phone support is stellar. No hold time during the day and they're very friendly. I got the feeling they were not trying to just rush through to the next call.
Oh one last thing, if you transfer a domain to hover.com, they automatically assign the nameservers to their current location. It's a nice touch.
Moniker also preserves nameserver settings during transfer. Actually, I think that's normal. Imagine the breakage if any registrar didn't preserve nameservers during transfer.

A couple years ago I moved to gandi.net. They have a large selection of TLDs (which has come in handy for my needs) and I like the interface. I've heard the customer service is good but I've not needed to see for myself yet. I will never do business with GoDaddy; their advertising is sensationalist and immature, and their CEO is a PoS...IMO.
I use dynadot, great prices and support. Without the bloat ads of Godaddy.
@shacker godaddy never did for me. And exactly, the breakage was awesome.
+1 for dynadot
I moved there based on a rec by @jacobian

moved 5 domains to namecheap from go daddy, so far so good, took advantage of the deal they had after the elephant disaster,, they extended all my dates from godaddy, so it was a great deal..ie I had a domain with 2 years left on it at godaddy and now it has three at namecheap..(I just paid for one at namecheap)
Good post. I'm in search of a new place for my domains, where jackasses like Bob Parson don't get to shoot elephants for funsies.
I use pairnic.com because of the absence of upselling, pricing transparency and simple uncluttered interface.
+1 for gandi.net; although I don't have any .com names there, they have the cheapest .im prices by about $50.
Just signed-up for name.com. We'll see how it goes.
